author: Stubborn_Virus
title: An Orthodontist's Worst Nightmare!
review:
So, you've got a bit of money on hand, just enough to grab a Mixel punk. But is this guy worth it? Well, let's have a look.

Box/Instructions

All the parts come in a clear plastic bag, with a folded set of instructions next to it. I've had issues in the past with the clear bag being stuck to the outer bag, stuck where the seams are sealed. Luckily, this didn't happen this time, but it can, so if you're completely worried about keeping the bags intact, be warned. Other than that, it's just a standard Mixel bag.

Parts

Well, it's green. Of the 53 pieces, only 46 go into the guy, the others going into the Nixel. The Trans-Green wings are pretty uncommon, as are, surprisingly, the Trans-Neon-Green cheese slopes. You get some parts for articulation, always useful, but other than that, there's not much. 

The build

Pretty simple. He's the first dragon-form Mixel punk I ever picked up, so I can't compare to others. Didn't take long. The Nixel was pretty standard, being the version with the 3 ears. 

The completed model

Well, the legs don't move much, but that's not the point of him- it's the wings. He can flap 'em, and his tail is pretty flexible, with a balljoint on his butt and a hinge in the middle. The head is on a balljoint, but there's no jaw- just a nasty looking underbite. The Nixel's existance allows for some play combat. Dragon verses little black cube- it's like Beowulf, only worse!

Overall opinion

This guy's living on borrowed time. He'll become spare parts soon. As he is, he's probably my least favorite of this trio. As novel as the idea of a snot dragon may be, he really doesn't deliver as a set. He's got some decent parts, however, and 53 parts for 5 bucks isn't horrible. And at the very least, he can always terrorize your Lego City setup!
